Sinuhe.Action: Writes diligently on a scroll of papyrus at age 95, showing sustained mental acuity and commitment to his work.
Remains undisturbed by environmental distractions like a small whirlwind, suggesting focused concentration and discipline.
Continues writing his memoir calmly and with clear knowledge despite physical frailty, showing reflective and sincere nature.
Observes surroundings with calm and ironic humor, indicating tolerance and acceptance.
Mentions exile and presence of soldiers as guards without bitterness, showing composure but emotional restraint.
Writes clearly and incisively despite physical signs of age and fatigue, showing crystallized knowledge and intellectual clarity.
Maintains alert, intelligent eyes reflecting calm wisdom and mature humor even in the face of death.
Smiles at and speaks to lizards as if they are friends and companions, showing loneliness but a gentle attitude.
Acknowledges his bitterness and isolation but still attempts to share his story sincerely with any listeners.
Continues writing his story despite old age and weariness, showing persistence and self-reflection.
Acknowledges uncertainty about the future and his ability to finish writing, showing realistic self-assessment.
Speaks to lizards as companions, possibly indicating loneliness and limited human interaction.
Walks to a slave who has dropped senseless from starvation and exhaustion.
Observes the difficult labor conditions and shows concern by walking to a slave who has dropped senseless from starvation and exhaustion.
Stands watching the labor rather than intervening actively to improve conditions or efficiency.
Bends over the slave who drops senseless, examines him closely, but shows no expression of horror, recognizing this as daily life.
Kneels to bleed a wealthy noble, performing his duty with care and attention.
Examines a starving slave carefully and diagnoses that he is dead, showing calm and unemotional acceptance of harsh realities.
Bleeds a wealthy noble using instruments of his time, demonstrating medical skill and confidence in his profession.
Drops his medicine chest on the Noble's swollen foot causing pain and anger, then calmly walks away with indifference.
Passes through a poor, dirty street calmly, unaffected by others' anger and dirt hitting his robe, continuing on his way professionally.
Passes by a dead body wrapped carelessly, observes as everyday occurrence without visible emotion.
Watches prisoners led to slavery, his face hardens with anger.
Carries his portable medicine case confidently to make a professional visit in a harsh environment.
Observes the dead body and prisoners calmly and with hardened anger, indicating awareness and emotional control.
Only observes suffering and injustice without intervening or taking direct action at this moment.
Looks Horemheb in the face calmly despite being brought as a prisoner with bound elbows, does not prostrate himself.
Maintains calm eye contact with Horemheb and does not prostrate himself before the throne despite expectation.
Responds to Horemheb's rage with a slight ironic smile, showing detachment rather than conciliatory or warm behavior.
Does not prostrate himself before Horemheb, looks him calmly in the face despite the hostility.
Maintains an ironic smile in response to Horemheb's rage and the tearing off of the emblem.
Cuts off the human connection during the moment of shared memory with Horemheb, showing emotional control.
Responds to Horemheb's banishment with irony and a smile, accepts fate without bitterness or protest.
Shows restraint and dignity when being harshly condemned, refrains from anger or retaliation.
Neither displays overt friendliness nor seeks confrontation in this passage, maintaining composure.
Responds to Horemheb's banishment with calm irony and a smile, accepts fate without visible distress or rashness.
Maintains composure during a harsh public judgement, demonstrates emotional control and dignified restraint.
Attempts to kill the lion by hurling a spear as it leaps over the chariot, showing initiative and quick reaction.
Misses the spear throw and breaks the spear on the rock, indicating a failure in skill or precision under pressure.
Lays waterlilies at the shrine base, a gesture of respect or devotion.
Comes to Akhnaton after the chariot crash, expressing concern by saying 'Don't you know you could have been killed!'
Is angry after the accident but directs concern rather than blame.
Attempts to shoot the lion over the backs of the horses but is unable to get a clear shot.
Gets thrown from the chariot after it overturns in an effort to protect Akhnaton.
Confronts Akhnaton angrily, warning him that he could have been killed.
Goes to Akhnaton when he collapses and attends to him by rolling him over, preventing choking, and washing his forehead.
Shows amused disgust at Akhnaton's proclamation but still helps him.
Calmly addresses the situation and takes practical steps to help an unconscious person.
Recognizes and explains that Akhnaton worships Aton, the sun god, showing awareness and understanding.
Responds practically and promptly to Akhnaton’s collapse by rolling him onto his back and inserting a linen strip to prevent tongue swallowing.
Washes Akhnaton’s forehead with dampened cloth, following a sensible care procedure after fainting.
Remarks with amused disgust at Akhnaton’s religious fervor and condition rather than showing concern.
Shows a somewhat dismissive, amused attitude toward Akhnaton’s 'holy sickness,' possibly underestimating the seriousness.
Attempts to help the unconscious young man, explains he is a physician, shows concern.
Shows astonishment and anger when accused harshly by Eie and Horemheb, indicating defensiveness rather than friendliness.
Explains calmly and assertively that he is a physician when confronted angrily by Eie.
Looks on with astonishment and asks 'What now?' showing uncertainty and lack of control over the situation.
Enters the scene almost as astonished as Horemheb, showing surprise rather than control or understanding.
Stares worriedly at the situation, indicating awareness but also concern without immediate action.
Raises his head sharply at the sound of Akhnaton's voice and tries to see him despite the crowd.
Excitedly and apprehensively alerts Horemheb about the discovery of Pharaoh's identity, whispering to him.
Warns others about the law and consequences ('Don't you know the law? We touched him! We'll lose our heads for it!')
Succinctly says farewell to Horemheb despite the court laughter, showing restrained dignity but no warmth displayed
Throws himself on his face before the throne and offers customary, respectful salutation to Pharaoh, showing sincerity and respect
Responds contritely and respectfully after Pharaoh commands him to stand and look, showing humility and respect
Remains silent when about to defend himself before Akhnaton.
Openly shares the painful story of being an orphan and cast adrift on the Nile.
Grows afraid for Horemheb and tries to signal him to make the proper reverence to the Pharaoh.
Grows afraid for Horemheb and tries to signal him to act appropriately in a tense moment before the throne.
Passively watches Horemheb's embarrassing failure without intervening further or correcting the situation.
Tries to smile bravely at Horemheb, shows courage and openness in a tense situation.
Looks openly at Akhnaton before accepting the death sentence.
Faces the threat of execution calmly, tries to smile bravely, shows no panic.
Looks openly at Akhnaton with apparent acceptance of fate.
Does not attempt to argue, plead, or resist the sentence.
Kneels and bows his head humbly before Akhnaton, showing respect and submission.
Looks up at Akhnaton as one delivered from the dead, showing gratitude and reverence.
Extends a hand behind him which is grasped by Horemheb, indicating trust and friendliness.
Is overwhelmed and cannot believe his good fortune when receiving honors, showing sincerity and emotional openness.
Feels joy at his own good fortune but immediately notices he has neglected his friend Horemheb and looks at him asking pardon.
Is tense and afraid during Horemheb's execution scene, showing emotional sensitivity to his friend's fate.
Feels overwhelmed and unable to immediately act when his personal joy is quenched by the sudden summons of Horemheb, showing sensitivity but some lack of presence in the moment.
Looks at Horemheb asking pardon, acknowledging his friend's predicament and showing social awareness and humility.
Is tense and afraid during the execution scene, indicating emotional vulnerability under pressure.
Breathes a deep breath of relief at a tense moment.
Rushes to pick up the jeweled collar and other honors carelessly tossed down in the courtroom.
Frantically gathers the honors ignored by Horemheb.
Breathes a deep breath of relief after the Executioner's near action on Horemheb.
Startled by the jeweled collar tossed down by Akhnaton, rushes to pick it up while others ignore it.
Frantically gathers the honors tossed down by Akhnaton which Horemheb ignores.
Laughs and makes light-hearted, friendly banter with Horemheb, showing warmth and camaraderie.
Expresses a complex, sincere view about love and emotional vulnerability.
Jestingly flaunts jewelry while maintaining a playful attitude, indicating a friendly and open mood.
Shows confident social ease and humor while interacting with Horemheb, displaying wit and charm despite emotional complexity about love.
Acknowledges the difficulty of love and its effects on personal power, demonstrating emotional insight and self-awareness.
Despite emotional turmoil, he maintains a lighthearted and composed demeanor in social settings.
Does not show visible indecision or confusion about his situation; proceeds confidently with plans for the evening.
Hides Pharaoh's jewelry in his cloak and instructs Horemheb to do the same, aiming to take someone by surprise at the table.
Pays no heed to Kaptah's desperate pitch to become his slave, ignoring a possibly distracting or annoying presence.
Tosses a few coppers as alms to Kaptah to get rid of him, treating him like a beggar rather than as a person.
Unaware of Kaptah's closer attachment and Horemheb's observation, indicating inattentiveness to others around him.
Smiles with eager anticipation when seeing Merit, showing friendly or warm regard toward her.
Tosses a few coppers as alms to Kaptah, treating him merely as a beggar to get rid of him.
Fails to notice Kaptah’s persistent presence and the fact that he is more than a mere beggar.
Carefully hides Pharaoh’s jewelry upon seeing Merit, showing awareness and discretion.
Smiles with eager anticipation upon seeing Merit, indicating social confidence and control over personal impression.
Smiles with eager anticipation upon seeing Merit and tries to engage her warmly by displaying Pharaoh's honors and offering a customary compliment.
Grabs Merit's skirt to stop her from leaving despite her reluctance to engage, showing a somewhat forceful demand for attention.
Expresses frustration and confusion toward Merit's distant and indifferent behavior.
Opens his cloak to reveal Pharaoh’s honors hoping to impress Merit and communicate significance.
Fails to perceive that Merit ignores his display and is not engaging with him; misinterprets her behavior as caprice.
Attempts to use polite, poetic language to engage Merit, but receives no response, showing a lack of effective communication.
Grasps Merit’s skirt impulsively to prevent her leaving, showing poor control over social interaction and emotional impulse.
Seems genuinely puzzled and confused by Merit’s aloofness and sharp replies, indicating a lack of situational awareness.
Attempts to assert himself confidently by confronting Merit and following her when she leaves, showing decisiveness and emotional engagement.
His social awkwardness and inability to handle the delicate situation with Merit tactfully, given her rebuffs and harsh words, suggest a lack of social or emotional savvy.
Despite the tension and Merit’s bitterness, he maintains poise and tries to lighten the mood with laughter, demonstrating emotional control and resilience.
Takes Merit in his arms, caresses her, showing an attempt at intimacy.
Agrees to go to the party nearby despite Merit’s anger, with a tone of angry humor.
Responds to Merit’s fury with a sarcastic, cutting remark ('And may your precious virtue warm you like a woolen blanket on cold winter nights').
Accepts Kaptah as a servant without objection or concern.
Agrees to go to the party despite being goaded from both sides, showing adaptability and social awareness.
Accepts the suggestion to hire a carrying chair for himself and his slave without hesitation, indicating decisiveness and practical management.
Attempts a cutting remark to Merit ('And may your precious virtue warm you like a woolen blanket on cold winter nights?') as they part, showing wit and social confidence.
Does not push Merit to explain her feelings or attempt reconciliation after her angry rejection, which could be seen as emotional reticence or avoidance.
Shows discomfort after quarrel with Merit, looks around cautiously in unfamiliar surroundings
Enters an unfamiliar environment with Horemheb and observes surroundings cautiously, showing awareness despite discomfort.
Appears uncomfortable due to a personal quarrel, contrasting with Horemheb's ease in the same situation.
Smiles after Horemheb, receives a flower garland and an invitation from a lady; politely declines and excuses himself with gestures.
Moves away trying to be inconspicuous despite being an uninvited guest; accepts honey cake offered by a girl slave despite embarrassment.
Takes honey cake when offered despite feeling like an uninvited guest.
Feels sharp guilt and apologizes for being uninvited.
Strokes Nefer's cat, glad to have something to do, showing gentle and considerate behavior.
Engages Nefer politely and apologizes for his presence, showing respect and sincerity.
Takes honey cake and wine despite being an uninvited guest, showing social awareness but calmly navigating the situation.
Notices Nefer and feels both attraction and guilt simultaneously, showing emotional complexity but no loss of composure.
Pretends to be interested in a mural to avoid awkwardness, demonstrating social tact and adaptability.
Interacts with Nefer's cat to have something to do, managing discomfort and engaging the situation skillfully.
Approaches Nefer somewhat awkwardly but respectfully and apologetically for intruding, balancing confidence with humility.
Keeps his hand gently held by Nefer and looks at her sincerely.
Expresses hesitation to stay due to his low status and lack of gifts, showing modesty and respect.
Admits to seeing women only in a professional, doctor-like manner, showing sincerity and restraint.
Withdraws politely from Nefer despite evident mutual interest.
Maintains professional restraint and honesty by admitting he views women only through a physician's clinical eyes, showing self-awareness and integrity.
Withdraws from pursuing Nefer romantically, citing his lower social standing and lack of gifts, showing realistic self-assessment and emotional control.
Demonstrates social awkwardness or lack of confidence in romantic/social situations by retreating rather than engaging fully.
Earnestly tries to give away Pharaoh's chains, showing sincerity and a desire to give value to others.
Hypnotized and quietly attentive beside Nefer, indicating patient attentiveness.
Seems fixated and intense about Nefer, pulses pounding; possibly emotionally vulnerable but not intrusive.
Insists on staying with Nefer despite her warning to leave and potential danger to his well-being.
Attempts to give away Pharaoh's chains (symbols of value and honor) impulsively, showing lack of strategic thinking.
Recognizes the emotional complexity of Nefer and tries to engage honestly despite risks.
Seated quietly observing Nefer and surroundings, appears distracted by passing slave woman.
Shows anger and stubbornness when rejected by Nefer.
Reluctantly strips himself of honors given by Akhnaton.
Remains stubborn and does not immediately leave despite Nefer's dismissive and mocking attitude.
Displays visible anger and flushes at Nefer's mention of a merchant and future plans, indicating emotional reaction that may cloud judgment.
After hesitation, methodically strips himself of honors given by Akhnaton, showing deliberate control and acceptance of consequences.
Drops honors into the ebony box despite personal dislike, showing integrity and acceptance of consequences.
Responds to Nefer's accusation of deceit with violent protest, showing frustration rather than openness.
Smiles at Nefer and thinks all is well, showing momentary warmth and affection.
Speaks enthusiastically and inclusively to fellow physicians and students, encouraging pride and happiness.
Respectfully addresses fellow physicians and students, attempts careful demonstration despite internal distraction.
Shows concern for patient’s pain, interacts politely and cautiously.
Unconsciously blurts out dependence on instruments, then quickly apologizes.
Mentally distracted by thoughts of Nefer during important professional moment.
Suddenly commands assistant physician to finish surgery, then rushes away from the courtyard, surprising onlookers.
Hurries toward the gate carrying an important scroll, showing purposeful movement amid tension.
Initially raises arm to strike Kaptah in anger but restrains himself upon seeing Kaptah's patience.
Becomes angry and desperate upon seeing the Babylonian merchant leaving Nefer's gate with signs of wealth and influence, and pushes through the closing gate and doors to chase him.
Brings the deed to Nefer late at night, responds calmly to servant's impertinence, and stays respectfully outside Nefer's bedroom before joining her.
Looks with cynicism momentarily at the merchant leaving Nefer's gate.
Rushes through the door just before it is closed, showing awareness and timely action.
Looks wildly about but quickly assesses the situation to find the adjoining room where lights are being extinguished.
Stops and looks about when the servant is extinguishing lights, showing caution and observation.
Replies confidently to Nefer's question with his name, establishing identity calmly.
Shows a moment of cynicism and thinks about the merchant leaving Nefer's gate, indicating critical thinking but slightly distracted.
Drops the deed discreetly into Nefer's ebony box, indicating careful and deliberate handling of important matters.
Kneels beside Nefer's bed, takes her hands, allows his head to rest against her breast, expressing tenderness and longing.
Speaks harshly to Nefer when she asks about his father's house, saying 'I cannot give you what is not mine.'
Kneels beside Nefer's bed, shows emotional vulnerability and restraint by not claiming possessions that are not his.
Harshly denies Nefer knowledge of his father's house, indicating protective discretion rather than carelessness.
Arrives at army barracks tired and expecting a disagreeable interview but still manages formal approach and engagement with Horemheb.
Interrupts Merit harshly and shows sarcasm when she tries to express her feelings.
Studies Merit calmly and walks across the room to meet her look despite initial harshness.
Acknowledges Merit’s determination quietly but refuses to engage sincerely.
He immediately dismisses assisting Merit directly and suggests she see the new doctor, showing decisiveness and confidence.
He interrupts and challenges Merit harshly multiple times, indicating emotional defensiveness rather than calm reasoning.
He studies Merit carefully and recognizes her true intent despite her efforts to control herself, demonstrating perceptiveness and insight.
He refuses to acknowledge his own guilt or despair, pushing Merit away out of contempt or self-reproach, showing an inability to confront his inner issues clearly.
Drives with harsher cruelty when seeing Merit about to cry.
Offers Merit to sign the deed to his inheritance despite her horror and protests.
Looks after Merit as she runs out in sobs, then slowly picks up the document without spirit.
Impulsively attempts to deed his inheritance to Merit in a moment of despair without considering consequences.
Stops himself from further harsh cruelty when seeing Merit break into tears, indicating some self-control.
Appears emotionally overwhelmed and half-drugged with shame when entering Nefer's garden, showing lack of confidence and control over himself.
Deeds to Nefer the home of his parents, offering her a significant personal gift.
Hesitates before handing over the deed, showing internal conflict and restraint.
Notes the diamond on Nefer's headpiece with quiet tension, indicating distrust or suspicion.
After Nefer cynically remarks about deceiving a merchant, Sinuhe violently attacks Nefer by grabbing her throat and throwing her into the pool.
Attempts to drown Nefer with the intent to kill her.
Attempts to drown Nefer deliberately, showing aggression and physical strength but reckless and violent behavior.
Fails to overcome opponents (the two Negroes) who rescue Nefer and overpower him easily, showing lack of control and vulnerability.
Is thrown out of the gate helplessly after being beaten and overpowered, indicating loss of situational control and poor outcome from his aggressive act.
Demonstrates medical knowledge relevant to saving the Pharaoh's child, inspiring hope despite others' doubts.
Absence from the scene despite urgent need, leaving others to take responsibility.
Known as a young physician whose demonstrated skill recently impressed the court; is believed to be the only one capable of saving Pharaoh's sick child.
Is found unconscious, dirty and bloody on the ground after presumably being handled roughly, indicating a moment of vulnerability or failure to protect himself.
Stands horror-stricken beside the shroud-wrapped bodies of his parents who have ended their lives, showing deep emotional reaction.
Stands looking about him, horror-stricken, after a severe beating; shows strong emotional reaction but no immediate action.
Reflects on his parents' death with suffering and bitterness, acknowledges the sorrow and pain involved.
Reads aloud with emotion his parents’ loving letter, showing openness to his parents' feelings and blessing.
Knocks aside workers who disrespect the dead woman’s body and shroud.
Brings and lays his parents’ bodies into the House of Death for preservation, shows respect for them.
Refers to himself as 'He Who Is Alone' and invokes his name in the Book of Life of the Physicians.
Seizes Foreman desperately and volunteers to work to pay debts despite being scorned.
Insists no man there is better than him, showing pride in hardship.
Seizes the Foreman desperately and offers to work for him to pay his debt, showing initiative and willingness to take responsibility despite his lowly position.
Insists boldly that no man there is better than him despite the Foreman's disdain, indicating confidence and self-assuredness.
Fails to have money to pay for transporting his parents, requiring a loan from his former slave, which shows a lack of resources or planning.
Acknowledges gratitude toward Kaptah despite his bad humor and the grave robber despite his unlawful trade, showing politeness and a sense of fairness.
Refers to grave robber as 'a kind man though a grave robber' with a rueful half laugh, indicating a tolerant and good-natured attitude even toward those of questionable morality.
Says to Merit 'Stay away!' and shows signs of withdrawal due to mourning, implying emotional distance and guardedness.
Accepts Merit's simple invitation to sit beside her despite his feeling of being shunned
Hesitates and looks down at Merit for a long time, showing internal conflict before embracing her
He watches Merit quietly, understands why she has come, but takes time to process it fully.
Stoops swiftly and gathers Merit into his arms, showing decisiveness and confidence.
Wakes suddenly and immediately looks for Merit, showing alertness and presence of mind.
Calmly accepts Horemheb's abrupt accusations and violence without reacting aggressively.
Resignedly acknowledges Horemheb's authority and fate, showing composure and a kind of sincerity.
Allows himself to be treated roughly and expelled without protest, showing restraint and tolerance.
Does not retaliate or respond with hostility despite Horemheb's violent behavior and harsh words.
Maintains calmness and resignation in the face of confrontation and accusation by Horemheb.
Accepts being forcibly taken and exiled without resistance, showing composed acceptance but no active defense or strategy.
Holds the purse, feeling gratitude for Horemheb's friendship.
Looks around, wondering where to hide, shows caution and concern for safety.
Responds to Kaphtah's distant call and goes toward him despite danger.
Hides quickly and cleverly from approaching soldiers, using doorways and timing to avoid detection.
Looks around cautiously, assessing where to be safe before moving.
Responds promptly to Kapatah's signals and follows direction towards safety and the ship.
Reflects sadly on his youth follies and exile, revealing vulnerability and sincerity.
Expresses deep yearning for home and connection to his roots, indicating emotional openness and sincerity.
Shows weariness and continues journey in foreign lands with companion Kaptah, suggesting loyalty and companionship.
Reflects on past follies and exile with sadness and insight, showing self-awareness and a capacity for learning.
Travels through many foreign lands, observing cultures and gods, indicating adaptability and broad knowledge.
Appears weary and seedy after years away from home, possibly indicating diminished vitality or effectiveness.
Looks around like an alien in a strange land but returns Kaptah's look for a long moment before responding
Smiles when discussing the power of gold with Kaptah, but does not dismiss the idea
Rises beside King Aziru after examining the sick boy, showing readiness to help
Negotiates a higher reward for saving a son, demonstrating strategic confidence.
Diagnoses a severe condition realistically but presents it as a simple infection to the others, indicating practical skill and discretion.
Faces an intimidating king boldly and uses subtle humor (toothache) in a tense situation, showing confidence and psychological insight.
Whispers with amusement to Kaptah about the King of Babylon’s toothache, displays boldness.
Boldly looks at the King of Babylon after the doctor shows fear.
States his fee with pride, claiming his skill will amaze.
Carefully examines Prince Shubbiluliuma’s injured eye with focus and professionalism.
Engages thoughtfully, indicating a pause between question and answer, showing respect and consideration.
Takes a delicate foreign particle from the Prince's eye with skill and humor, sharing a laugh with the Prince.
Analyzes the military map and cautiously interprets a possible Hittite invasion despite not being a military man, demonstrating thoughtful intelligence and humility.
Successfully removes a foreign particle from the Prince's eye using precise medical instruments and conceals it skillfully, showing technical skill and calm under pressure.
Engages diplomatically with the Prince, responds with wit about his fee, and maintains composure amidst the tense atmosphere, reflecting confidence and social competence.
Bows respectfully to Prince Shubb and walks away quietly with Kaptah.
Greets a Hittite armorer friend with a smile and nod.
Politely inquires about the new metal removed from the prince's eye, showing interest and respect.
Tries to gain knowledge from the armorer despite the armorer's refusal to answer.
Offers all his jewels and those of Kaptah to the armorer to obtain the iron spearhead without bargaining or insult.
Pressures Kaptah to give up his valued possessions despite Kaptah's distress.
Recognizes the superior quality of iron by testing it against the anvil, showing knowledge and insight.
Acquires the iron spearhead by silently offering his jeweled possessions without bargaining, displaying cleverness and confidence in negotiation.
Ignores Kaptah's emotional pleas and takes his valuables to secure the spearhead, demonstrating tactical decisiveness but risking interpersonal conflict.
Takes the spearhead with joy, sees it as a passport to return home
Shares his hope and excitement about returning to Egypt with Kaptah
Stops to give alms to a beggar woman and child despite limited resources.
Reassures himself by feeling his concealed weapon, showing caution.
Moves cautiously and alert when entering dangerous areas, shows awareness and carefulness.
Conceals a Hittite spearhead on his person as a precaution, indicating foresight and preparedness.
Stops to give alms to a beggar woman despite limited resources to gain information, demonstrating diplomatic skill and strategic thinking.
Reassures himself about reaching the barracks, showing some confidence but possibly also underlying anxiety.
Gives money to the beggar woman despite her venomous accusation against the Pharaoh.
Stops to observe the suffering crowd and questions the cause of civil unrest with genuine concern.
Reassures frightened Kaptah and leads him forward through a tense and dangerous situation.
Shows genuine surprise when hearing criticism of Pharaoh Akhnaton, indicating awareness and open-mindedness.
Gives money directly to the beggar woman, demonstrating decisiveness and compassion in handling the situation.
Observes the situation at the granaries and assesses the risk posed by the crowd versus the soldiers.
Takes hold of Kapteah and directs him to move toward the barracks despite Kapteah’s fear, showing leadership and confidence.
Takes hold of Kaptaah to guide him despite Kaptaah's fear.
Politely requests to see Horemheb, showing respect to authority.
Takes hold of frightened Kapteah and leads him confidently towards the barracks despite danger.
Requests permission to see Horemheb calmly and confidently, gaining access through the guarded gate.
Insists the valuable object is for Horemheb alone, showing stubbornness and respect for authority.
Attempts to remain calm despite suspicion and rough treatment, showing composure and restraint.
Tries to escape when recognized and restrained, prioritizing self-preservation over openness.
Stubbornly insists the valuable item is for Horemheb alone despite the Lieutenant's demand, showing resolve.
Senses danger and averts his face when recognized, trying to remain calm under pressure.
Attempts to escape when recognized but is quickly subdued by officers and soldiers.
Carries a concealed Hittite spearhead but it falls and is lost during the struggle, which diminishes his tactical advantage.
After the spearhead falls, tries to pick it up despite being restrained but is prevented by the Lieutenant stepping on it.
Hotly protests to Lieutenant, claiming friendship and pleading to be taken to Horemheb
Sits in despair and does not eat the unspeakable prison food
Prostrates himself on the floor in respect upon seeing Princess Baketamon.
Despite being in chains and a prisoner, he manages to prostrate himself respectfully before Princess Baketamon, showing self-control and presence of mind.
His amazement and inability to move initially can be seen as a momentary hesitation or lack of immediate control of the situation.
Accepts and endures the indignities of captivity without resistance, which may reflect prudence and understanding of court politics rather than rashness.
Raises his head to look after the Princess in amazement, showing alertness and awareness of a pivotal moment.
Listens attentively as Taia shares her personal story without interrupting or mocking.
Momentarily entertains a chilling thought about Taia but quickly abandons it as ridiculous, showing self-restraint and tolerance.
Does not laugh when Taia admits using her beauty to charm Pharaoh, indicating respect and sincerity.
Shows noticeable tension and focus on Taia's story, indicating empathy and engagement.
Shows detailed recall and knowledge about the time and conditions of his birth and abandonment, responding confidently to Taia's probing questions.
Briefly entertains a chilling thought but abandons it as ridiculous, indicating mental control and avoidance of distraction.
Is startled by Taia's comment but quickly recovers and continues the conversation smoothly.
Responds calmly and politely to Taia's provocative suggestion by joking that she has drunk too much ale.
Asks permission politely before leaving Taia's presence.
Avoids confrontation and does not escalate the tense situation.
Shakes off a bad dream and composes himself before facing the officer.
Throws himself on the floor before the throne, admits to a great crime and accepts punishment.
Is forcibly dragged by Horemheb to the throne room, passively submits without resistance.
Allows himself to be dragged by Horemheb and throws himself on the floor before the throne, demonstrating acceptance of guilt and readiness to face punishment.
Stays silent and out of view initially in the throne room crowd, appearing passive in a tense political situation.
Approaches Akhnaton with wonder, responds calmly to Akhnaton's gentle tone, and sits close to him in a moment of intimacy and trust.
Brings the Hittite spearhead with him, possibly showing guardedness or suspicion despite Akhnaton's invitation.
Keeps the spearhead out of Akhnaton's sight when asked to sit near him, indicating respect and restraint.
Takes the Hittite spearhead from the table on his way to the throne, presumably to use it as part of his counsel to Akhnaton.
Responds with wonder and amazement to the Pharaoh's unexpected gentle and informal tone, showing he is attentive and adaptable.
Cautiously keeps the spearhead out of Akhnaton's sight after the Pharaoh orders him to keep it away, showing awareness and respect for authority coupled with strategic restraint.
Prepares to share his worldly knowledge and wisdom with the Pharaoh when invited, indicating confidence and readiness to contribute skillfully.
Expresses a sorrowful and disillusioned view of rulers and gods, showing empathy toward the meek and poor who suffer.
Listens with visible worry to Akhnaton's weakness and plea for help.
Admits he cannot help with spiritual or emotional healing despite feeling moved by Pharaoh’s words.
Does not dismiss Akhnaton’s idealism, but openly expresses doubt about the world being as the Pharaoh imagines.
Reflects on the harsh realities of rulers and gods, showing insight into human nature and skepticism toward idealism.
Acknowledges his own limitations openly when he says he can heal bodies but does not understand spiritual matters or the pharaoh's god.
Responds with trouble and worry to the pharaoh's weakness and grand task, showing empathy and awareness of complex situations.
Does not offer direct solutions or concrete help to Akhnaton despite being asked for assistance, indicating a possible hesitation or lack of confidence in helping with spiritual matters.
Looks at Akhnaton with worry after Akhnaton is exhausted and almost fainting.
Stops and reaches for purse to give alms to a beggar, then smiles warmly upon recognizing Kaptah.
Silently leaves Kaptah behind at the Inn without warning, causing Kaptah to be surprised and run after him.
Calls off with a strong voice to steward to attend the King despite the tense situation.
Carries and hides the Hittite spearhead discreetly beneath his clothing, indicating caution and awareness.
Automatically reaches for purse to give alms without immediately recognizing Kaptah, showing momentary absentmindedness.
Recognizes Kaptah quickly and engages with him, demonstrating social awareness and memory.
Silent exit into the Inn, losing Kaptah unexpectedly, which shows a small lapse in communication or consideration.
Quickly catches up to Merit after she turns away, showing attentiveness and engagement.
Shows pleasure at Merit's piqued reaction, indicating he values her feelings.
Touches the cross on Merit's clothing while speaking, suggesting a gentle and sincere approach.
Hesitates upon first seeing Merit, revealing a moment of uncertainty or distance.
Quickly catches Merit at the temple gate after she tries to leave, showing alertness and social sensitivity.
Shows slight hesitation and fails to instantly recognize Merit upon seeing her, revealing a momentary lapse in attention.
Chases cheerfully after Merit when she walks away, asking where she is going and if he may walk with her.
Attempts to conciliate Merit, asking her not to be angry with him.
Shows slight alarm and seriousness when Merit accuses him of leaving without a word and then disappears.
Laughs and uses exaggerated, comedic language to express devotion, saying he has whispered her name to the winds and sent greetings with swallows.
Chases cheerfully after Merit, attempts to walk with her and conciliates her after tension.
Says something exaggerated and comical to deflect from a difficult question about using his talents conscientiously.
Appears slightly alarmed and unable to resolve conflict quickly when Merit leaves; disappears through gates without fully explaining.
Confesses yearning for Merit and remembers only her when offered friendship.
Grows serious and reaches for her hand, showing sincerity and connection.
Laughs with Merit and engages in light-hearted banter, showing friendliness.
Expresses cynicism and disbelief in gods, dismissing faith sincerely held by Merit.
Stops walking abruptly, astonished by something Merit does, showing attentiveness.
Engages in thoughtful banter and maintains control of emotional expression, hiding a truth beneath apparent joking.
Shows insight by being impressed with Merit’s depth of conviction despite skepticism.
Demonstrates critical thinking by rejecting simplistic beliefs after extensive experience.
Abruptly stops walking when surprised by Merit’s unexpected action, showing alertness and adaptability.
Expresses curiosity about Merit and her past, gently questions her about her living situation.
Shows astonishment and concern upon seeing Thoth injured, offers to help examine the boy.
Expresses astonishment appropriately and follows Merit and Kaptah with curiosity; offers to examine Thoth's wounds promptly.
Fails to immediately understand the significance of Merit’s hesitance or the full context of the street and its inhabitants beyond superficial curiosity.
Looks almost angrily at Merit’s house and questions if it was once his parents' home, then later agrees to help the child despite initial irritation.
Throws a penetrating look at Merit that flusters her, indicating some coldness or tension in their interaction.
Shows innocent tone and attention on his actions when confronting Merit about the boy's mother.
Smiles believing Merit's explanation about the boy, showing trust.
Gives Hittite spearhead as a present from one orphan to another, showing kindness and empathy.
Gives the boy a friendly push ahead, indicating friendliness and warmth.
Wanders over to see cooking and enjoys the smell of frying fish, displaying a relaxed and friendly demeanor.
Reminisces fondly about childhood and shares this with Thoth.
Expresses feeling of being at home for the first time.
Treats wounded and sick refugees and followers of the Cross with care and dedication.
Works cooperatively with Thoth, showing mutual affection.
Treats the wounded and sick refugees in the temple grounds, attends to patients patiently and skillfully.
Engages an assistant (Thoth) and displays a bond of affection indicating effective teamwork and leadership.
Sits calmly by the fish pond reflecting on feeling of belonging, showing emotional composure and self-awareness.
Gives money to a poor mother for her sick child without hesitation.
Evades the mother's attempt to kiss his hand, signaling for the next patient instead.
Approves of Thoth's worried diagnosis and shows mild smile toward Kaptah's joking.
Smiles mildly toward Kaptah and laughs, but with seriousness in his eyes, showing understanding and compassion.
Responds with consideration to Horemheb about his woman and her adopted son, showing concern for their safety.
Takes Thoth's hand, indicating solidarity and reassurance.
Examines an old crippled woman's twisted arm with care and gravity, showing empathy and a sincere desire to help.
Shows hesitation and internal conflict ('My mind agrees with you - but something in me wishes.'), indicating inward warmth and complexity rather than coldness.
Interrupts his work to speak with Horemheb, but shows a polite excuse ('I have been busy'), not dismissive or rude.
Looks at the woman’s piteous appeal, feels internal conflict, and decides to help by undertaking her cure and providing instructions for medicine.
Initially reacts with hatred and triumph at the woman’s condition but then suppresses these feelings as pity and compassion take over.
Responds thoughtfully and with restraint to Akhnaton's despair by acknowledging uncertainty and avoiding harsh judgment.
Shakes his head thoughtfully and offers a measured, contemplative response to Akhnaton's despair, demonstrating calm reasoning amid chaos.
Looks at Akhnaton with pity, places a cold cloth on his head, and tells him to rest.
Assumes a light, jesting tone to deflect Horemheb and Ele, showing reluctance to engage with their conspiratorial atmosphere.
Wrings out a fresh cold cloth and places it on Akhnaton's head, showing care and calmness under emotional strain.
Remains silent when urged to take a painful action against Akhnaton, indicating thoughtful restraint and internal conflict.
Avoids Horemheb and Ele who appear conspiratorial, showing his awareness and caution.
Uses a light, jesting tone to deflect suspicion and maintain composure when confronted about his whereabouts, demonstrating social skill and tact.
Expresses careful skepticism about curing Akhnaton’s pain, indicating realistic and thoughtful approach.
Refers to Horemheb’s threat as put in a loving tone and calls him friend, showing tolerance and some warmth in relationships.
Shows hesitation and moral boundary by stating 'Only murder is my affair', indicating integrity but also emotional distance or coldness in political matters.
Forgives a sharp rebuke and gently deflects sensitive comments about Akhnaton’s plea, showing restraint and some kindness.
Agrees to see Baketamon despite knowing potential danger; shows willingness to engage on Horemheb's behalf.
Responds to Horemheb's plan with wry amusement and curiosity, indicating tolerant and sincere engagement.
Maintains a conciliatory tone and listens before acting, showing patience and respect.
Does not immediately reject or react negatively to Horemheb’s plan of forced marriage, suggesting a measured and non-hostile demeanor.
Shows cautious curiosity and agrees to see Baketamon after considering the risks and implications.
Responds to the surprising news of Horemheb's rise with astonishment but remains engaged and willing to play a role.
Does not immediately jump to conclusions or rash actions but seeks to understand the political situation and his role within it.
Appears wryly amused and curious, indicating a confident and skillful attitude toward uncertain events.
Speaks to Baketamon with courtesy despite her coldness and hostility, maintaining respectful dialogue.
Responds carefully to Baketamon's aggressive statements and accusations, showing restraint and tact.
Challenges Baketamon's harsh judgment of Horemheb, defending him calmly and respectfully.
Mocks Baketamon by suggesting her maidenhood has gone to her head and recommending marriage as a cure, a pointed and somewhat cruel remark.
Teases Baketamon with a wise smile and playful words, engaging warmly in their interaction.
Reacts with bewilderment after Baketamon's passionate kiss, showing a sincere, human emotional response.
Listens to Baketamon's angry disclosure about political plots and abuse, responding with composure and respect.
Expresses admiration for Horemheb's plan despite its violent intent, showing detachment and impression rather than moral judgment.
Engages in witty, confident banter with Baketamon, responding with a wise smile and clever remarks.
Maintains composure while discussing plans and threats, despite being confronted with emotional and dangerous information.
Expresses bewilderment after Baketamon kisses him with passion, indicating some emotional confusion or lack of control.
Shows quick understanding of Horemheb’s plan and is impressed by its neatness, indicating intelligence and perceptiveness.
Does not interrupt the passionate anger and disclosure of Baketamon's dangerous situation, but instead listens carefully and stays engaged.
Allows Baketamon to hold his hands and sit close, showing receptiveness and vulnerability despite bewilderment.
Silent contemplation and emotional movement when observing the statue of the potential mother, showing depth of feeling and sincerity.
Does not reject or dismiss Baketamon's startling claims but rather considers them seriously, showing tolerance and openness.
Reflects deeply on the overwhelming and bewildering information about his possible royal heritage, showing capacity for critical thought and emotional processing.
Does not immediately reject or accept the extraordinary claims about his origin but considers evidence (such as the statue) thoughtfully.
Appears overwhelmed and bewildered by conflicting thoughts and emotions, indicating uncertainty and hesitation in decision-making.
Is deeply moved by the statue, showing emotional sensitivity and a quest for connection with his past.
Grips Merit roughly by the shoulders momentarily, showing intensity but possibly lacking gentleness.
Shares his secret with Merit and appeals for her to escape the palace corruption together with him and the boy.
Expresses conflicted feelings about his royal birthright and the palace’s crime and intrigue.
Expresses deep emotional dependence saying 'I cannot live without you!'
Responds with practical concern by suggesting an alternate entrance to avoid attackers ('We can get in through the side gate')
Calmly climbs onto a heap of ruined wall to gain a comprehensive view of the attacking forces.
Analyzes the enemy’s movement and suggests an alternative entry point: 'We can get in through the side gate.'
Treats the sick and injured at the temple grounds despite the dangerous situation.
Gives clear instructions to organize the wounded into a line for treatment.
Expresses concern and notices Kaptah's bruises and torn clothing, implying empathy.
Remarks to Kaptah about being on the wrong side of the wall with a hint of gentle reproach, showing some sternness.
Works quickly and diligently helping the wounded during battle.
Annoyed when interrupted by Kaptah as Merit arrives with Thoth.
Works quickly to tend many wounded despite chaotic and dangerous conditions.
Annoyed when interrupted by Kaptah while working, showing some irritation but remains focused on task.
Tells Merit to 'wait your turn' and 'in line' while he works on a wounded man, despite her frantic pleas that the wounded is her son.
Works feverishly and furiously to save the wounded man, showing commitment and urgency in a critical situation.
Turns away from a frantic woman pleading to save her son, insisting 'Wait your turn!' and 'In line,' then works furiously and skillfully on wounded men despite emotional difficulty.
Despite knowledge that the boy has bled to death, continues to examine him and looks to Merit with pleading eyes, showing composed professionalism amidst personal anguish.
Finds Merit’s body among the dead, carries her to the altar, and covers her with altar cloth
Walks past a faintly alive woman reaching out for help and says 'Help yourself!'
Refuses to help a faintly alive woman who reaches out to him for help, responding coldly with 'Help yourself'
Agrees to participate in the plan to give poison to Akhnaton in a way that involves camaraderie ('when you and I drink with him')
Requests privacy and a cleared pantry to work alone without concern for others’ comfort or presence
Closes the door to keep the guard outside, carefully prepares three goblets with wine and a mysterious liquid, and drinks olive oil before proceeding.
Brings the tray with three drinking cups of wine to Horemheb with a strange smile and speaks calmly.
Follows Horemheb quietly to Akhnaton's room and participates in the peaceful gesture of drinking wine as a token of friendship.
Follows Horemheb into Akhnaton's room quietly and waits calmly, showing self-control and situational awareness.
Nods subtly to Horemheb to assure him about the safety of offering the wine, demonstrating understanding and silent communication in a tense situation.
Nods to Horemheb, seemingly attentive and respectful in a tense moment.
Makes a half-gesture too late to intervene as Akhnaton drinks and then dies.
Listens silently and respectfully to Akhnaton's final words and death.
Does not openly express overt grief or emotional reaction, remains composed.
Responds with a half-gesture too late to Akhnaton's sudden swift motion, showing lack of readiness or quick reaction.
Maintains composure and presence after Akhnaton's death, silently acknowledging the gravity of the moment.
Dares to support Horemheb's claim to Pharaoh despite risks and insults, shows faith in enduring truth over earthly power.
Speaks scornfully to Horemheb about the weight of the crown and the futility of worldly glory.
Dares to challenge Horemheb by throwing the crown at him and declaring he has made him Pharaoh, showing boldness and confidence.
Speaks with scorn and philosophical insight on the heavy burden of the crown and the fate of Egypt, indicating deep understanding and intelligence.
Uses Akhnaton's last words to justify his audacious act, showing strategic thinking and awareness of larger historical forces.
Declares he will speak to common people as one of them, showing empathy and equality.
Proclaims that all men are equal regardless of appearance or status, judged only by their heart and justice.
Admits to seeking knowledge above all else, showing humility and sincerity.
Responds calmly and with increasing fervor to Horemheb's scorn, clearly articulating a plan to continue spreading his beliefs despite danger and opposition.
Accepts impending defeat by Horemheb but confidently asserts that his ideas and influence will persist among the common people.
Recognizes the power of truth and justice beyond social hierarchies and expresses it wisely to others.
Runs eagerly to Merit after graduation to share his achievement and links arms with her; shows pride and openness.
Pauses and reveals a thoughtful, faraway look when walking with Merit; shares an honest moment of reflection.

Princess Baketamon.Action: Orders the removal of Sinuhe's chains and arranges for him to be bathed, dressed in fine linen, and taken to the palace.
